attachments.title: NumPy: function for simultaneous max() and min()
attachments.text: numpy.amax() will find the max value in an array, and numpy.amin() does the same for the min value. If I want to find both max and min, I have to call both functions, which requires passing over t...
attachments.fallback: Stack Overflow: NumPy: function for simultaneous max() and min()

elements.text: oh wow, now I get Ian's comment:
this is great.  someone should post the answer with

text:
```In [1]: import numpy as np

In [2]: from julia import Base

In [3]: np.random.seed(1)
   ...: x = np.random.rand(1000000)

In [4]: %%timeit
   ...: np.amin(x), np.amax(x)
   ...: 
   ...: 
622 µs ± 3.04 µs per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 1000 loops each)

In [5]: %%timeit
   ...: Base.extrema(x)
   ...: 
   ...: 
8.18 ms ± 1.9 ms per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 1 loop each)```
wait... what? :grimacing:

elements.text:
In [1]: import numpy as np

In [2]: from julia import Base

In [3]: np.random.seed(1)
   ...: x = np.random.rand(1000000)

In [4]: %%timeit
   ...: np.amin(x), np.amax(x)
   ...: 
   ...: 
622 µs ± 3.04 µs per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 1000 loops each)

In [5]: %%timeit
   ...: Base.extrema(x)
   ...: 
   ...: 
8.18 ms ± 1.9 ms per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 1 loop each)
